node.title: N.Y.U. Skirball Season Reinvigorates the Classics
node.alt: Maggie Hoffman, on a chair, in Elevator Repair Service’s “Seagull,” inspired by Chekhov and directed by John Collins. It will kick off New York University’s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts’s season in February.
node.description: Elevator Repair Service will premiere a show inspired by Chekhov’s “The Seagull,” and the Classical Theater of Harlem’s hip-hop-infused “Seize the King” gets an encore.
node.content: ["Numerous high-profile Shakespeare productions will fill New York stages next year.", "Among them will be \u201cSeize the King,\u201d Will Power\u2019s contemporary spin on \u201cRichard III\u201d that was staged by the Classical Theater of Harlem in Marcus Garvey Park last summer, which is likely the only production that has a courting scene in a bathtub and that sprinkles in references to birth control and eating sushi with a fork.", "The 95-minute, hip-hop-infused reinterpretation of Shakespeare\u2019s classic will return from March 3 to March 13, as part of New York University\u2019s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts\u2019s new season, which was announced on Tuesday. Carl Cofield, who directed the summer production, will return as director.", "In her review of last summer\u2019s outdoor staging, the New York Times critic Laura Collins-Hughes deemed the show a Critic\u2019s Pick, praising its humorous reimagining of the classic characters. The production \u201ccontained multitudes of beauty,\u201d she wrote.", "Before \u201cSeize the King,\u201d the Skirball will kick off its season with the world premiere of Elevator Repair Service\u2019s \u201cSeagull,\u201d inspired by Anton Chekhov\u2019s classic drama \u201cThe Seagull\u201d and directed by John Collins (Feb. 2-20). Elevator Repair Service, a veteran theater company known for its unconventional takes on classic literary texts, staged \u201cGatz,\u201d an eight-hour reading of F. Scott Fitzgerald\u2019s novel \u201cThe Great Gatsby\u201d at the Skirball in 2019.", "\u201c\u2018Seagull\u2019 isn\u2019t a marathon\u201d like \u201cGatz,\u201d Jay Wegman, Skirball\u2019s director, said of the new production, which runs about two and a half hours. \u201cBut it\u2019s going to be whacked out in a wonderful way.\u201d", "The Skirball has also lined up the world premiere of an interactive online experience called \u201cI Agree to the Terms\u201d (March 25-April 3), created by the theater company Builders Association with input from \u201cmicroworkers\u201d who develop Amazon\u2019s algorithms. Audiences will complete virtual training sessions with these workers \u2014 taking them inside a sprawling and largely unregulated industry of people who earn pennies per click while completing assignments that are repetitive, boring, maddening and sometimes disturbing.", "\u201cThey\u2019ve done a few workshops, and it\u2019s anxiety-provoking in these sessions,\u201d said Wegman, who added that the show becomes a competition among audience members. \u201cYou\u2019re constantly being watched and counted and manipulated by the algorithm, so it\u2019s very timely.\u201d", "Rounding out the Skirball\u2019s season are a concert by the Spanish flamenco singer Miguel Poveda, who will make his New York City solo debut (April 7-8); the world premiere of David Dorfman Dance\u2019s \u201c(A)Way Out Of My Body\u201d (April 22-23); the New York premiere of the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Du Yun\u2019s \u201cZolle\u201d and \u201cA Cockroach\u2019s Tarantella,\u201d presented with International Contemporary Ensemble (April 29-30); and another New York premiere, the choreographer and MacArthur fellow Eiko Otake\u2019s \u201cThe Duet Project: Distance is Malleable\u201d (April 14-17).", "A full season lineup is available at nyuskirball.org."]
